Description: Small central part of a large pottery plate. Interior, thick white slip; three dilute lines at outside as preserved; within, elaborate frieze: filled triangle, three lotus buds alternately ordered and perhaps further triangle, with added red in centre of buds. Exterior preserves top of ring foot, stand surface lost, sides painted, probably on a white ground. On bottom of foot the letters sigma and iota (modern?).
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Robinson 1893 / Catalogue of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Vases (p. 212, no. 19)
Fairbanks 1928 / Early Vases preceding Athenian Black Figure Ware (p. 100, no. 302.5, pl. XXXII)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GO.471)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4695 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
